title: Women in TV made historic gains over the past year, but don’t get too excited
text:
Women have made promising strides in their representation on TV, a new study finds — but its author cautions there’s still plenty of progress to be made.

The share of female characters with speaking roles hit a recent historic high of 45% in 2018-2019, a bump from 40% in 2017-2018, according to the latest report from San Diego State University’s Center for the Study of Women in Television and Film. Some 45% of major characters on broadcast, cable and streaming TV were female, the report found, up from 40% in 2017-2018.

Meanwhile, women made up 31% — an increase from the previous record of 28% in 2016-2017 — of those working in top behind-the-camera gigs like directing, writing and producing. Women made up one in four creators, edging up from 22% during the previous year.

“It is heartening to see moderate but widespread gains for female characters and women working behind the scenes this year, but we need to consider the numbers within the larger context of women’s employment in television,” study author Martha Lauzen said in a statement.

For example, “in 2018-19, women comprised 26% of directors. This is a historic high, up from 17% in 2017-18,” she said. “However, men continue to direct the vast majority of programs. In this context, ‘historic high’ still means that men outnumber women 3 to 1 in this role.”

Adding to the reality check: More than half of programs had five or fewer women working in behind-the-camera roles measured, while just 3% of programs had 14 or more women occupying those jobs. On the flip side, 17% of programs had five or fewer men working behind the camera, and 38% had 14 or more men. Nearly all (96%) didn’t have any female directors of photography, while almost eight in 10 had zero female directors, editors or creators, respectively.

Female characters were also less likely than male ones to be identified by their job (66% versus 75%, respectively) and to be shown at work in their workplace (44% versus 56%). Moreover, they were far more likely than their male counterparts (53% versus 39%) to play roles oriented toward personal life, like a mother or wife, than to play roles oriented toward work.

Research suggests that the portrayal of women in popular TV shows and movies can influence viewers’ lives. A 2018 study by 21st Century Fox, the Geena Davis Institute and J. Walter Thompson Intelligence, for example, found that nine in 10 women familiar with “The X-Files” character Dana Scully said she was a role model for women and girls. Nearly two in three women working in STEM called her a personal role model.

Meanwhile, a study published earlier this year in the peer-reviewed Journal of Broadcasting and Electronic Media linked regular viewing of the women-led political dramas “Madam Secretary,” “Scandal” and “The Good Wife” with greater political interest (like following news about government and elections) and political self-efficacy (the extent to which they felt able to make a difference by participating in the election process).

And the more women work as creators, the greater the chances of women cropping up in other aspects of production, Lauzen’s study suggests: Programs that had at least one female creator “employed substantially greater percentages of women in other key behind-the-scenes roles and featured more female characters in major and speaking roles than programs with exclusively male creators,” she wrote.
description: ‘We need to consider the numbers within the larger context of women’s employment in television.’
